content.name: The House of Mouse
content.culture: Entertainment empire turned religious order worshipping its ancient founder
content.want: Spectacle. Content. Experiences that can be monetized across dimensions.
content.pay: Excellent if you're entertaining. Terrible if you're boring.
content.vibe: Terrifyingly cheerful. Everything is branded. NDAs have NDAs.

contracts.name: Creative Acquisition
contracts.desc: Enter a rift, document everything. Sketch creatures. Record environments.

contracts.name: Experience Design
contracts.desc: Scout locations for new House attractions. In other dimensions.

contracts.name: Talent Acquisition
contracts.desc: Find interesting rift entities. Convince them to perform. Somehow.

content.text: An ancient entertainment and media empire â€” the largest creator of stories, characters, and imagined worlds in human history. A thousand years later, the stories are scripture, the characters are saints, and the imagined worlds are blueprints for the real ones. The House of Mouse doesn't just own intellectual property â€” it IS intellectual property. Every creature design, every magical technique, every dimensional discovery made under the House's banner belongs to the House. Forever. Across all dimensions. Including ones that haven't been discovered yet. The legal framework for cross-dimensional IP was established six centuries ago and has never been successfully challenged, because challenging it requires surviving the legal department, and nobody survives the legal department.

content.label: Aesthetic
content.text: Black and gold. Elegant. Theatrical. Everything is a performance. Public spaces are stages. Architecture tells stories â€” every building has a narrative, every street has a theme, every district is a chapter. The Founder â€” a figure of almost divine creative power â€” is depicted everywhere. Smiling. Always smiling. The smile is warm. The eyes are not.

content.label: Citizens
content.text: Cast Members. Every citizen is a performer in an ongoing production that is the House itself. Roles are assigned. Costumes are provided. Lines are trained. Authenticity to the House's creative vision isn't just expected â€” it's the only measure of worth. The Inner Circle â€” those who've embodied their assigned characters so completely that the performance became identity â€” runs the House. They haven't broken character in generations.

They want content â€” unique species, environments, and phenomena to document, design around, and own. Every rift creature the House discovers is sketched, named, categorized, and copyrighted before the field team returns. If another corp discovers the same creature independently, the House's legal division will be in contact. The creature was theirs first. They have the paperwork.

Their Denial doctrine is defensive â€” protecting the House's proprietary discoveries from theft, replication, or unauthorized observation. If you see something that belongs to the House, you didn't see it. If you replicated something that belongs to the House, the Advocates are already en route.

content.label: Enforcement
content.text: The Advocates â€” the House of Mouse's enforcement arm. Part lawyer, part assassin, part performance artist. Every Advocate is a licensed legal professional, a trained combatant, and a true believer. They carry writs of enforcement alongside weapons. They'll serve you a cease-and-desist and a killing blow in the same motion, and both will be legally binding. Black suits, gold pins shaped like the House sigil. Always polite. The politeness is not reassuring.

Advocates are deployed for intellectual property violations: unauthorized creature reproduction, use of House-proprietary techniques, possession of cataloged specimens without license, or creating original content that is “confusingly similar” to existing House property. The definition of “confusingly similar” is determined by the House. It is always confusing. It is always similar.

content.label: Pay
content.text: Excellent. The House of Mouse is one of the wealthiest corps in the world and they pay contractors well. The catch: your contract includes IP clauses that assign everything you discover, create, or even think of during the contract period to the House. Technically, the interesting thought you had about rift topology while eating lunch is now House property. Enforcement of this clause is selective but not theoretical. An Advocate once filed a claim against a contractor's dream journal. The Advocate won.

Theatrical. Immaculate. Deeply unsettling. Everything is beautiful. The briefings are presentations with musical accompaniment. The equipment is elegant, well-designed, and embossed with the House sigil. The handlers are friendly, supportive, and watching you with the focused attention of people evaluating whether you're on-brand. You will sign more documents than any other corp. You will understand fewer of them. The food is themed. The lodging is themed. The mandatory team-building exercises are themed. At some point you'll realize that the entire experience has been designed to make you feel something specific, and that the feeling was planned before you arrived.

"All creative output generated during contracted engagement periods â€” including but not limited to observations, sketches, verbal descriptions, involuntary exclamations, and dreams occurring within 48 hours of mission completion â€” constitutes Work Product under Section 14(g) of the Standard Contribution Agreement. The House thanks you for your imagination. It belongs to us now."
